_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The management and employees of GRAINCO FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Serena fire department, LaSalle County LEPC or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling system consist of storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. Access to this site is restricted to authorized facility employee, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 



This facility has developed a worst case and alternative case scenario, however, since this is security sensitive information it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as required by EPA regulations. 



This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of the Compressed Gas Association's (CGA's) "American National Standard Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" (6th edition), commonly referred to as "ANSI/CGA G-2.1 2014", as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration(OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program. 

  

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:  

          -    have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor

          -    to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in plac

e,  property

               damage, or environmental damage.



This facility is a non responding facility. The facility has:

          -    a written action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29CFR 1910.38:

          -    provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know     

               information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Serena Fire Department and LaSalle County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC. 



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  We will be renewing our PPE requirements this December as well as our regular post-season facility inspection.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time. Satellite facility does visual inspections when utilizing  facility on maintenance and operating procedures.
